   I think we should avoid mentioning roles like "client" or "server" except non-normatively to emphasize that the spec would apply to both roles. What matters is that the entity's identity is a DNS name.

pulls.title: Tighten the wildcard rules
pulls.author: richsalz
pulls.body:
No wildcard characters in presented identifiers.

The * must only be in the left-most label, and must be the first or only
character in that label.

This is the first part of what was in draft-use-san.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: merged locally; closing.

Could we separate out this change from the rest of the changes here? I feel like a verifier should be able to reject a certificate for any reason, but this seems counter to that. At the same time, I don't think we should immediately reject this change.
"part or all of a label" is more general than what is intended--only accepting wildcards as the entire leftmost label.
This is actually a weaker requirement than what modern verifiers implement. They only accept wildcard certificates where the leftmost label is exactly "*".
This language supports reverting the "MAY to MUST" change you made.
Are you sure that `*foo.example.com` isn't supported?
This isn't correct; see https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man3/X509_check_host.html for example.
yes you are right.  i will undo that.

> Are you sure that `*foo.example.com` isn't supported?

The Baseline Requirements define:

> Wildcard Certificate: A Certificate containing an asterisk (*) in the left‐most position of
any of the Subject Fully‐Qualified Domain Names contained in the Certificate.
>
> Wildcard Domain Name: A Domain Name consisting of a single asterisk character
followed by a single full stop character (“*.”) followed by a Fully‐Qualified Domain Name

See https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1107791 for Firefox's behavior, at least back then when I implemented it.

See also https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=434960#c3: "Disallow support for a*.example.net, *a.example.net, and a*b.example.net in certificate wildcard handling," which appears to be the same.

I know my Rust webpki library always implements the strict "only *" form.
per following comment, this change is wrong; thanks.

> This isn't correct; see https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man3/X509_check_host.html for example.

OpenSSL might implement something different but I'm arguing that the stricter form should be the only one that is accepted.
@sleevi would be more up to date with what Chrome does. @mozkeeler would know what FIrefox does presently.
This is not just the webpki, but I get it. The WG will have to decide if "*foo.example.com" should be outlawed.

> OpenSSL might implement something different but I'm arguing that the stricter form should be the only one that is accepted.

https://github.com/richsalz/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/issues/3

@richsalz This came up during the drafting of RFC 6125, and captured in [Section 7.2](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6125#section-7.2)

Ignoring Chrome and Firefox here (which behave as Brian said; a wildcard is only allowed if it's the entire label), since they're more narrowly focused on WebPKI, the whole-label-only is also reflected in Security.framework (used by macOS/iOS/tvOS/watchOS for all verifications). The story on Windows is more complicated, since it's varied over time, and the construction you mention used to be allowed, but isn't on more recent versions in their strict mode (but I believe some compatibility may be retained for LDAPS)

comments.body: Is this intended to be in this PR? It looks unrelated. I see there are a lot of changes to quotes in this PR. Perhaps we should do those changes in a separate PR that focuses on such reformatting, and then rebase this on top of that or vice versa.

As was discussed previously on the mailing list, recommending or disallowing CAs to include CN-IDs in the subject CN is a separate issue from requiring relying parties to only use subjectAltName when validating a certificate for a DNS name.

At our strictest, I think we should continue to allow CAs to include any DNS name in subject CN that also appears (verbatim) in the subjectAltName as a dNSName or iPAddress.

Or, perhaps we just don't make any recommendations at all regarding the contents of the subject CN. The main purpose of revising this RFC is to make the subject CN irrelevant as far as certificate verification is concerned.

I don't understand how the browser gets "w3.example.com" from "www.example.com" here. Typical operation of a web browser would be to only have "www.example.com," no?

I think in this PR we should stick to removing the CN-ID from this example, changing "two reference identifiers" to "one reference identifier".

If we want to say something about more exotic name resolution stuff for web browsers, we should do that in a separate PR.

comments.body: This sentence does not parse well, and needs work.

The final clause ", known as ..." does not have a referent in the preceding content.  It is also far from clear how 6125(bis) rules should be applied when verifying client certificates, since there is very rarely a prior notion of the "reference identifier" against which to compare the presented identifiers when doing client authentication.

With STARTTLS one can imagine some pre-agreed identity exchanged prior to mutual TLS that server can then verify, but otherwise, all there are are just the presented identifiers, and the server can authorise or not authorise these for particular client requests.

So I'm not sure that imputing symmetry of roles in "mutual TLS" is reasonable. Generally I find that mutual TLS is often misunderstood, precisely by assuming the sort of symmetry that isn't actually there...

The terms "client" and "server" were correct as written, but perhaps worth saying somewhere that these are TLS-layer roles, and that the application could support the TLS server making requests of the TLS client after the TLS handshake, there is no requirement that the roles at that layer match the TLS-layer roles.

comments.body:
This is a bit of a nit, but since the reference is to IDNA-DEFS, perhaps it makes sense to keep the sequence ("visually similar characters") together, since that's the title of Section 4.4, since we're not referencing UTR39 directly, which calls them Confusable

```suggestion
Allowing internationalized domain names can lead to visually similar characters, also
referred to as "confusables", being included within certificates. For discussion, see
for example {{IDNA-DEFS, Section 4.4}} and {{UTS-39}}.
```

UTS-39 is the primary reference for this these days, and it seems like it's been acceptable to ref informative (e.g. [RFC 5894](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5894#ref-Unicode-UTS39)) or normative (e.g. [RFC 8266](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8266#ref-UTS39))

I realize this reintroduces the quotes you were getting rid of, but that seems to be the proper plural noun used to refer to these characters (e.g. 4.1, 4.2, and 6.1 of UTS 39). I'm less attached to the quotes, to be clear, but was trying to make some indicator of this being the actual term of art used.

```suggestion
(SNI) extension as discussed in {{TLS, Section 4.4.2.2}}.  If multiple
protocols share the same port, the client MUST use the Application-Layer
Protocol Negotiation as described in {{ALPN}} if the intended protocol has
registered Protocol ID {{SOME-REF-HERE}}.
```

Where {{SOME-REF-HERE}} would be reference to https://www.iana.org/assignments/tls-extensiontype-values/tls-extensiontype-values.xhtml#alpn-protocol-ids

There's probably a better way to smith this, and as (about to be) discussed on the list, this could be seen as superfluous.
Yeah, I dropped ALPN completely.
Thanks!  I took this wording, and added uts-39 as informative given the text above.

```suggestion
domains or protocols. TLS Extensions such as TLS Server
Name Identification (SNI), discussed in {{TLS, Section 4.4.2.2}},
and Application Layer Protocol Negotiation (ALPN), discussed in
{{ALPN}}, provide a way for the application to indicate the desired
identifier and protocol to the server, which can be used to select
the most appropriate certificate.
```

Note: GitHub won't allow suggestion to unmodified text, so this is roughly replacing the entire paragraph.

```markdown
This specification allows multiple DNS-IDs, SRV-IDs, or URI-IDs in a
certificate, which allows for a single application service to use the
same certificate for multiple identifiers. This enables a single certificate
to be used across multiple hostnames, such as when a client does not
support the TLS SNI extension, or across multiple protocols, such as
SMTP and HTTP, on a single hostname. The use of a single certificate
and public/private keypair in such environments MAY facilitate
cross-protocol attacks, particularly when used in differing TLS
configurations. See, for example, {{ALPCA}}, {{DROWN}}. Server
operators SHOULD take steps to mitigate the risk of cross-protocol
attacks, such as ensuring all TLS endpoints using a given certificate
support exactly the same TLS version(s) and ciphersuite(s), and
SHOULD make use of the TLS ALPN extension to ensure the correct
protocol is used.

## Multiple Reference Identifiers

This specification describes how a client may construct multiple
acceptable reference identifiers, and may match any of those reference
identifiers with the set of presented identifiers. {{PKIX, Section 4.2.1.10}}
describes a mechanism to allow CA certificates to be constrained in the
set of presented identifiers that they may include within server certificates.
However, these constraints only apply to the explicitly enumerated name
forms. For example, a CA that is only name constrained for DNS-IDs is not
constrained for SRV-IDs and URI-IDs, unless those name forms are also
explicitly included within the name constraints extension.

A client that constructs multiple reference identifiers of different types,
such as both DNS-ID and SRV-IDs, as described in
{#verify-reference-rules}, SHOULD take care to ensure that CAs issuing
such certificates are appropriately constrained. This MAY take the form of
local policy through agreement with the issuing CA, or MAY be enforced by
the client requiring that if one form of presented identifier is constrained,
such as a dNSName name constraint for DNS-IDs, then all other forms of
acceptable reference identities are also constrained, such as requiring a
uniformResourceIndicator name constraint for URI-IDs.
```

This is a huge mouthful, and is really meant to be a rough draft for starting discussion, because it definitely reads awkwardly. However, it tries to get the concept out, but I'm not entirely sure on the usage of the 2119 language here either.
I moved this into its own PR, #33.  I did a light editing pass and think the use of 2119 is fine.

comments.body:
Q: Isn't the usual editorial practice to expand the acronym fully on first use, and then use the acronym in subsequent usages?

I suspect this may get flagged in the editorial queue; I fully agree with changing the subsequent uses, but perhaps keeping these two (and line 172) is sufficient?

In thinking in terms of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5280#section-2.2 and https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5280#section-2.3 , and in line with the editorial tweak, it _might_ make sense to

```suggestion
reference identity so it can deterministically and automatically authenticate the communication.
```

That may be overkill though :) It is somewhat implicit in the "Out of Scope", but this just tries to tie it back as a positive scope expression rather than negative.

Was "relative domain name" (line 297) meant to be "Relative Distinguished Name"? I wasn't sure, and the expression makes sense with either, but wanted to flag (since "Naming of Application Services" doesn't get into the relativity discussion)

```suggestion
client's communication with the server. This removes
DNS and DNS resolution from the attack surface.
```

It's a suggestion. It feels a bit colloquial, but it could be entirely fine as-is, so feel free to reject :)

Did you also want to update (new) lines 632/633?

I was originally surprised by this edit, but with the overall simplifications for CN handling, and this definition is unambiguously present, I like this approach you're taking here. I could see an argument for 632/633 being similarly redundant, or I could see the argument for making sure to restate (during the high level) that these come from the certificate.

Just wanted to flag
"as a service" is today a buzzword-bingo term that may be misunderstood. You may want to delete those words.

In some scenarios ALPN is the "formal identifier for an application protocol".  I need to re-read the full text to see if this was just a stupid comment or something that makes sense. The "may" in my statement indicates that I was unsure. :-)
